awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: P2C2--Drivers for Past Variability in Tropospheric Reactive Halogens: Implications for Climate and Evaluation of Ice Core Proxies
awd_abstract_narration:
This project aims to examine reactive halogens and their impacts on the chemistry of the troposphere and stratosphere especially with regards to climate. Reactive halogens impact the oxidative capacity of the atmosphere thereby influencing reduced concentrations of trace gases such as methane CH4 and the abundance of short lived climate forcing agents such as ozone (O3) and aerosols in the atmosphere. 

Ice-core observations of the precursors and/or sinks of reactive halogens in the troposphere suggest both anthropogenic- and climate-induced changes in the abundance of reactive halogens in the troposphere. This has an, as of yet, unquantified impact on several paleoclimate proxies in ice cores.

The researchers plan to investigate the sensitivity of reactive halogen abundance to anthropogenic emissions and to climate change in a global model and examine its potential feedbacks on climate. As such, the project will focus on the following two research questions: (1) What are the biggest drivers for changes in the abundance of reactive halogens over the preindustrial-industrial and glacial-interglacial timescales; and (2) What are the potential implications for the oxidizing capacity of the atmosphere and short-lived climate forcing agents CH4, tropospheric O3, and aerosols.

The potential broader impacts include the potential to advance knowledge and understanding within atmospheric chemistry and climate and paleoclimatology, via potential improvement of the representation of reactive chemistry in global climate system models with interactive carbon simulation. The project supports the training graduate students in numerical modeling of atmospheric chemistry, outreach and education. It also provides for the wider community dissemination of research results of GEOS-CHEM model development through workshops and meeting sessions and public and K12 outreach and education efforts by the researchers.

por.por_cntn:
This project examined reactive halogen chemical species and their impacts on atmospheric composition, especially with regards to climate. Reactive halogens strongly impact the chemistry that processes and removes trace gases and condensed-phase particles from the atmosphere, thereby influencing the concentrations of pollutants and greenhouse gases like methane and near-surface ozone. Ice-core observations of the precursors and sinks of reactive halogen species suggest both anthropogenic- and climate-induced changes in the abundance of reactive halogens at and since the last Ice Age. As such, this project combined a new atmospheric chemistry model with observations to explore the drivers for changes in the abundance of reactive halogens over the preindustrial-industrial and glacial-interglacial timescales. The primary outcomes of the project were twofold: (1) the improvement of the representation of the reactive halogen chemistry in the GEOS-Chem global atmospheric chemistry model (http://www.geos-chem.org), which is used by hundreds of scientists in dozens of countries; and (2) the development and public hosting of a new model framework that is capable of simulating reactive chemistry across multiple periods the last Ice Age cycle (http://atmos.earth.rochester.edu/giss-gc), now in use by several research groups to interpret ice-core measurements, and with no access restrictions. The results were published in open-access peer-reviewed journals and presented at scientific conferences, and the project supported the development and training of two graduate students from groups underrepresented in the Geosciences.
